utterance: Unidentified Speaker: about we can make the expertise. So this is I think job part is going to convince all of the society to move from one part to the other one. This is these are my two cents.

utterance: David Koweek: There's some evidence that folks aren't so eager to jump industries even when there's opportunities to transition from carbon-rich industries to renewable energy industries and so I think we should be careful about the assumption that just because we try to stand up new industries for carbon removal or renewable energy that folks are going to be on board and wanting to do that. I think it'll require a fair amount of incentives, you know removing incentives and subsidies from fossil fuels and potentially standing them up on zero carbon or negative carbon industries to help that transition.

Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.explanation: The speaker provides factual information by stating 'There's some evidence that folks aren't so eager to jump industries' to inform the discussion about industry transitions.
Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.score_justification: The contribution is relevant and provides concrete detail about a challenge in industry transition, making it highly valuable.

Evaluation & Feedback.explanation: The speaker critiques an underlying assumption by stating 'I think we should be careful about the assumption that just because we try to stand up new industries... that folks are going to be on board'.
Evaluation & Feedback.score_justification: The critique is constructive, provides reasoning, and suggests a more nuanced understanding of the problem.

Idea Generation & Development.explanation: The speaker expands on the discussion by proposing a solution: 'it'll require a fair amount of incentives, you know removing incentives and subsidies from fossil fuels and potentially standing them up on zero carbon or negative carbon industries'.
Idea Generation & Development.score_justification: The idea is elaborated with specific, concrete examples of incentives, making it highly actionable and relevant.

utterance: Roger Aines: as long as we're talking about the issues of the more societal aspects of decarbonizing the economy which which I think we should would be a good idea to sort of decide whether or not that's something we we really want to tackle here or if it's more the technological or scientific aspects or to what degree that they they connect in in a way that we could address meaningfully. But I just wanted to throw in that there are clearly social license aspects along the lines we've been talking about in terms of getting buy-in from society.

Process & Task Management.score_justification: The utterance provides a clear and specific suggestion for structuring the discussion by defining the scope (societal vs. technological aspects and their connection), which helps move the team forward effectively.

Idea Generation & Development.explanation: The speaker introduces the specific concept of 'social license aspects' as an expansion on the previously discussed societal issues related to decarbonizing the economy.
Idea Generation & Development.score_justification: The utterance introduces a specific, relevant concept ('social license aspects') that builds on an existing idea, providing a concrete and elaborated contribution to the discussion.

utterance: Peter Reiners: But one that I've seen that I'm also concerned about and Julia articulated this well in a way I hadn't heard is the mitigation avoidance protestation which actually I find to be common among scientists that we shouldn't even be thinking about these things because it is an avoidance of what we should be doing to reduce emissions in the first place. And at least in the scientific circles that I work in I meet up with a lot of resistance to even seriously talking about many of the fascinating and important and inevitably necessary technologies and science that we're talking about. I'm not sure that that's something we want to focus on here but it's just something that I find to be an obstacle in the circles that I work in.

Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.explanation: Peter shares his personal observation and experience regarding 'mitigation avoidance protestation' among scientists in his circles, providing factual information about a common resistance to discussing certain technologies.
Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.score_justification: The contribution is highly relevant and provides concrete details about the observed phenomenon and its context, making it high-quality.

Information Seeking & Gap Identification.explanation: Peter explicitly identifies an 'obstacle' in scientific circles, highlighting a gap in willingness to seriously discuss necessary technologies due to 'mitigation avoidance protestation'.
Information Seeking & Gap Identification.score_justification: The utterance clearly and specifically identifies a significant obstacle/gap in the scientific community's engagement with certain topics, providing concrete details.

utterance: Jane Zelikova: Yeah and this is like literally the fodder for our work. I think something that Peter said really resonated for me which is that the idea of like sort of the the social dimensions of this work and I know that a lot of us here would maybe consider ourselves to be more on the technical expert side and I think what we really need is to be working with social scientists who are really thinking about the societal sort of like how society perceives new technology or new approaches how they gain traction how those perceptions shift over time and like really needing to work with social scientists to formulate our research questions to formulate our research approaches and make sure that the work that we're doing is really grounded in the social dimensions of carbon removal and climate mitigation. So and I think from an and that includes economists that includes folks that are thinking about technology deployment that includes policy makers and folks that work in the policy space more generally. So that's kind of like where I'm landing now that we can't really decarbonize the economy without engaging deeply and meaningfully with the social sciences.

Idea Generation & Development.explanation: Jane expands on the existing idea of social dimensions by proposing a new approach: integrating social scientists to formulate research questions and approaches, providing examples of relevant fields.
Idea Generation & Development.score_justification: The utterance introduces a novel and relevant approach, elaborating on it with specific details and examples that move the team's thinking forward.

Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.explanation: Jane signals her expertise by stating the topic is 'literally the fodder for our work' and identifies the group's general expertise as 'more on the technical expert side.'
Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.score_justification: She provides concrete and relevant information about her own work's focus and the team's expertise, which is highly relevant to the discussion.

utterance: Julia Brown: our experience in the UK from our climate assembly where we got the parliament convened a group of of citizens who represent the diversity at all sorts of in all sorts of ways of the UK population was that that people are more sympathetic to natural solutions like tree planting and peatland restoration and solutions to do with accelerated weathering and things like that then they are to technologies that require us to store CO2 underground where people were quite nervous about the connotations of that and people were were more taken by creating aggregate that stored CO2 that you could put into building materials and things like that.

Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.explanation: Julia provides factual information from her team's experience in the UK climate assembly, detailing public perception of different carbon removal technologies, which directly relates to the ongoing discussion about social dimensions.
Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.score_justification: The utterance provides relevant and concrete details from a specific experience (UK climate assembly), offering specific examples of public perception towards different carbon removal technologies, which significantly enriches the discussion.

utterance: Andrea Hicks: Right so life cycle assessment typically relies on generalized inventories if you don't have particular inventories. So you can think about like anthracite mining right so it's a type of coal in the US. Europe's been a bit ahead of us on all of this in terms of developing the types of databases you use and Ecoinvent is one of the big ones. The US has the US life cycle inventory from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory which has some of the processes but it's missing so you usually need to fill in. And the USDA E-PACT actually has been putting together a lot of the agricultural databases. I mean agriculture is a little bit interesting right because like depending how you produce a kilogram of corn it could be vastly different in terms of things like added amendments water energy. So I mean I think the US is lagging a little bit behind on the actual inventory data to characterize our systems whereas Europe's been doing it for a while.

Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.explanation: Andrea provides factual information about life cycle assessment, specific databases like Ecoinvent and US life cycle inventory, and compares the US and European approaches to inventory data, fulfilling Marcel's request for her expertise.
Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.score_justification: Andrea provides highly relevant and concrete details about specific databases, their limitations, and comparative progress between regions, directly addressing the group's need for expert knowledge.
